content: The Navajo Reservation boundary is clarified to include trust lands of the Navajo Tribe as of January 1, 2015. Land reselection is allowed to correct surveying errors. The Navajo Tribe is allowed to deselect and reselect up to 757 acres of land to correct surveying errors. Any lands deselected will be taken out of trust and managed by the Bureau of Land Management. Additionally, a report on fair rental value payments is required. The Secretary of the Interior must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of this Act, detailing rental decisions between the Navajo and Hopi Tribes from 2001 to 2014, including any delays and pending appeals. The Secretary of the Interior must report to Congress on rental decisions between the Navajo and Hopi Tribes from 2001 to 2014, including any delays and pending appeals. The report should also address the role of contracts with the Bureau of Indian Affairs under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, funding levels for functions, and contract provisions. The report should also address the role of contracts with the Bureau of Indian Affairs under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, funding levels for functions, and contract provisions. Additionally, the report should include details on the total amount paid by the Navajo Tribe as rent and interest, as well as a plan to bring initial rental determinations current through 2015 as of April 1, 2016. The Secretary of the Interior must report to Congress on rental decisions between the Navajo and Hopi Tribes from 2001 to 2014, including any delays and pending appeals. The report should also address the role of contracts with the Bureau of Indian Affairs under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, funding levels for functions, and contract provisions. Additionally, there should be a plan to ensure that all annual rental determinations are completed and delivered to the tribes by April 1 of each year starting from 2017. The Navajo Tribe Sovereignty Empowerment Demonstration Project is outlined in Section 4. The Navajo Tribe has the authority to designate up to 150,000 acres as Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zones within specific lands on the Navajo Reservation. This includes lands selected by the tribe, lands west of the Executive Order Reservation of 1882, and lands partitioned to the tribe. Within the Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zones, the Navajo Tribe has the option to waive certain laws, such as the Wilderness Act, for renewable energy, housing, infrastructure, and economic development, subject to approval by regulatory bodies. The laws that can be waived within the Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zones for development purposes include The Wilderness Act, The National Environmental Policy Act, The Endangered Species Act, The Federal Land Policy and Management Act, The National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act, The Fish and Wildlife Act, The Fish and Wildlife Coordination Act, and The Administrative Procedure Act. The Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zones allow for the waiver of certain laws for development, including The Wilderness Act, The National Environmental Policy Act, The Endangered Species Act, The Federal Land Policy and Management Act, The National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act, The Fish and Wildlife Act, The Fish and Wildlife Coordination Act, and The Administrative Procedure Act. Specific exemptions apply to projects within the Grand Canyon rim. Additionally, savings can be transferred to the Navajo Tribe by federal agencies. Federal agencies must consult with the Navajo Tribe to determine the cost savings for implementing laws in Navajo Empowerment Zones, ensuring it is not less than what would have been provided for program operations. The Navajo Tribe receives funds annually to implement tribal law in Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zones. Federal agency decisions made in this regard are final and can be appealed in Federal district court. (d) Civil Jurisdiction. All individuals and entities in a Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zone are under the civil and regulatory jurisdiction of the Navajo Tribe. Judgments by the Navajo Tribe are recognized by other courts. (e) Tribal Sovereignty. Navajo Nation laws and treaties with the United States remain in effect within the Zones. The Navajo Tribe's eligibility for funding and grants under the Navajo-Hopi Dispute Settlement Act of 1996 or other US laws is not affected by this section. SEC. 5. RELINQUISHMENT OF ACCOMMODATION AGREEMENT AND ELIGIBILITY FOR RELOCATION BENEFITS. The Navajo-Hopi Land Dispute Settlement Act of 1996 is amended to include a new section regarding the relinquishment of accommodation agreements and eligibility for relocation benefits. The Navajo head of household can relinquish an Accommodation Agreement within two years and receive full relocation benefits, including housing and counseling. If the head of household is no longer in that role, their successor is entitled to the benefits. The Navajo head of household can relinquish an Accommodation Agreement within two years to receive full relocation benefits from the Office of Navajo and Hopi Indian Relocation. SEC. 6. NAVAJO REHABILITATION TRUST FUND. Section 32 of Public Law 93-531 (25 U.S.C. 640d-30) is amended to allow the Navajo Tribe to use funds for development in the Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zones. Additionally, changes are made to subsections (f) and (g) of the law.
